items.synopsis: The ASX opens unexpectedly lower on the last day of the 2022-23 financial year after the Australian Energy Regulator charges AGL for failing to meet its obligations under the National Electricity Rules. Follow live.

title.children: Federal government's budget surplus swells to $19 billion, AGL charged by energy regulator, ASX higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: You read that right — to expand on Gareth's post a little earlier, the government has crunched some numbers today and found the 2022-23 budget surplus was a mammoth $19 billion. Not only that, but the net debt is down to $516.7 billion. That is quite the substantial turnaround — just last month, the federal government noted its cash underlying surplus was just $8.9 billion, whereas now it's a staggering $20.4 billion. It sure does make that modest $4.2 billion budget surplus we heard about on budget night much, much smaller in comparison. As economist Chris Richardson points out, the sudden appearance of funds comes at a time when the economy is slowing, and household budgets are feeling the strain. So why the big turnaround? "The biggest contributor was that Treasury hadn’t fully allowed for the impact of war and inflation on the nation’s finances," Mr Richardson wrote. If you want to get elbows deep in the data on a Friday afternoon, be my guest — I've linked it below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Federal budget surplus now $19 billion for 2022-23 financial year

featuredLink.title: Australian Government General Government Sector Monthly Financial Statements for May 2023 | Department of Finance

children.content: You read that right — to expand on Gareth's post a little earlier, the government has crunched some numbers today and found the
2022-23 budget surplus was a mammoth $19 billion
Not only that, but the net debt is down to $516.7 billion.
That is quite the substantial turnaround — just last month, the federal government noted its cash underlying surplus was just $8.9 billion, whereas now it's a staggering $20.4 billion.
It sure does make that modest $4.2 billion budget surplus we heard about on budget night much, much smaller in comparison.
As economist Chris Richardson points out, the sudden appearance of funds comes at a time when the economy is slowing, and household budgets are feeling the strain.
"The biggest contributor was that Treasury hadn’t fully allowed for the impact of war and inflation on the nation’s finances," Mr Richardson wrote.
If you want to get elbows deep in the data on a Friday afternoon, be my guest — I've linked it below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There's a growing number of Australians who are selling homes they've bought less than two years ago, with an "unusual number" choosing to sell at a loss. If you fall into that category, we'd like to hear from you and why you've chosen to sell. Is it because of rising interest rates? Moving interstate? Are you downsizing? Or is it for a different reason altogether? Let us know by following the link below to a contact box and tel us your story — one of our reporters might just get in touch for a chat.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Have you sold your home, even though you only bought it in the past couple of years?

featuredLink.title: Have you recently sold your home, having only bought it within the past couple of years?

children.content: There's a growing number of Australians who are selling homes they've bought less than two years ago, with an "unusual number" choosing to sell at a loss.
If you fall into that category, we'd like to hear from you and why you've chosen to sell.
Is it because of rising interest rates? Moving interstate? Are you downsizing? Or is it for a different reason altogether?
Let us know by following the link below to a contact box and tel us your story — one of our reporters might just get in touch for a chat.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Link Administration is shaping up to be the worst performer on the market today — so far it's plummeted 13.4%, and there's around an hour and a half of trading left for the day. So what's caused it? It's all because of superannuation giant HESTA not renewing their contract with the business. Link has provided administration services to the super fund under a nine-year contract, but HESTA won't renew the contract once the current one runs out and will transition out by the second quarter of the 2025 financial year. HESTA makes up around 4% of Link's estimated group revenue for FY23, but Link says its guidance for its operating earnings before interest and taxes will be "slightly above the upper end of the 10-12% guidance range". Moving forward, HESTA will partner with Grow Inc for its administration services.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What's behind the falling Link Administration share price?

children.content: Link Administration is shaping up to be the worst performer on the market today — so far it's plummeted 13.4%, and there's around an hour and a half of trading left for the day.
So what's caused it? It's all because of superannuation giant HESTA not renewing their contract with the business.

Link has provided administration services to the super fund under a nine-year contract, but HESTA won't renew the contract once the current one runs out and will transition out by the second quarter of the 2025 financial year.

HESTA makes up around 4% of Link's estimated group revenue for FY23, but Link says its guidance for its operating earnings before interest and taxes will be "slightly above the upper end of the 10-12% guidance range".
Moving forward, HESTA will partner with Grow Inc for its administration services.
